HiWelcome to the MedHelp forum!Yes, it is possible to faint or lose consciousness or muscle tone while laughing or any other activity. What you suffer from is probably a vasovagal syncope or a vasovagal attack. The complex group of symptoms is mediated by the vagus nerve. This nerve is irritated by prolonged standing, standing up suddenly, stress, pain, hunger, dehydration, intense emotion etc. A tilt table test, holter monitor, echocardiogram etc are done for confirmed diagnosis. Discuss this with your doctor.The other possibility is gelastic seizures. These are seizure triggered by laughing and other such activities and include fainting, shaking, stony appearance, head falling back, loss of muscle tone, proper seizures etc. You need to consult a neurologist regarding this.Extreme fatigue could be due to anemia, diabetes, hypothyroidism, or due to kidney or liver problems. Another possibility is sleep disturbances (like sleep apnea, imbalance of rapid eye and non rapid eye movement sleep etc.). You may sleep your customary 7-8 hours and yet feel fatigued. You need sleep studies to rule this out. Other possibilities are chronic fatigue syndrome, depression, low Vit b12, low iron, low calcium, sodium and potassium. Hyperthyroidism too causes increased sweating and tiredness.   A comprehensive investigation is required keeping all the points in mind. Do discuss this with your doctor and get yourself examined. Hope this helps. Take care!
